title: Proposition 47
prose:
Let {polygon ABC} be a right-angled triangle having the right-angle {angle BAC}.
I say that the square on {line BC} is equal to the (sum of the) squares on {line BA} and {line AC}.

For let the square {polygon BDEC} have been described on {line BC}, and (the squares) {polygon GB} and {polygon HC} on {line AB} and {line AC} (respectively) [Prop. 1.46].
And let {line AL} have been drawn through point {point A}, parallel to either of {line BD} or {line CE} [Prop. 1.31].
And let {line AD} and {line FC} have been joined.
And since angles {angle BAC} and {angle BAG} are each right-angles, then two straight-lines {line AC} and {line AG}, not lying on the same side, make the (sum of the) adjacent angles equal to two right-angles at the same point {point A} on some straight-line {line BA}.
Thus, {line CA} is straight-on to {line AG} [Prop. 1.14].
So, for the same (reasons), {line BA} is also straight-on to {line AH}.
And since angle {angle DBC} is equal to {angle FBA}, for (they are) both right-angles, let {angle ABC} have been added to both.
Thus, the whole (angle) {angle DBA} is equal to the whole (angle) {angle FBC}.
And since {line DB} is equal to {line BC}, and {line FB} to {line BA}, the two (straight-lines) {line DB}, {line BA} are equal to the two (straight-lines) {line CB}, {line BF}, respectively.
And angle {angle DBA} (is) equal to angle {angle FBC}.
Thus, the base {line AD} [is] equal to the base {line FC}, and the triangle {polygon ABD} is equal to the triangle {polygon FBC} [Prop. 1.4].
And parallelogram {polygon BL} [is] double (the area) of triangle {polygon ABD}.
For they have the same base, {line BD}, and are between the same parallels, {line BD} and {line AL} [Prop. 1.41].
And square {polygon GB} is double (the area) of triangle {polygon FBC}.
For again they have the same base, {line FB}, and are between the same parallels, {line FB} and {line GC} [Prop. 1.41].
Thus, the parallelogram {polygon BL} is also equal to the square {polygon GB}.
So, similarly, {line AE} and {line BK} being joined, the parallelogram {polygon CL} can be shown (to be) equal to the square {polygon HC}.
Thus, the whole square {polygon BDEC} is equal to the (sum of the) two squares {polygon GB} and {polygon HC}.
And the square {polygon BDEC} is described on {line BC}, and the (squares) {polygon GB} and {polygon HC} on {line BA} and {line AC} (respectively).
Thus, the square on the side {line BC} is equal to the (sum of the) squares on the sides {line BA} and {line AC}.

Thus, in a right-angled triangle, the square on the side subtending the right-angle is equal to the (sum of the) squares on the sides surrounding the right-[angle].
(Which is) the very thing it was required to show.
